# Definition of Absolute Value

::: {.callout-note title="ğŸ“– Definition"}
The **absolute value** (or modulus) of a real number \(x\) is defined as:

\[
|x| =
\begin{cases}
 x, & \text{if } x \ge 0, \\
 -x, & \text{if } x < 0.
\end{cases}
\]
:::

---

# Geometric Interpretation
- The absolute value represents the **distance from \(x\) to the origin** on the real line.  
- Therefore, \(|x|\ge 0\) for every \(x \in \mathbb{R}\).

![](../images/imagem1-modulo1_3.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Absolute Value"}

---

# Properties of Absolute Value

::: {.callout-important title="ğŸ“ Main Properties"}
1. \(|x|\ge 0\) and \(|x|=0 \iff x=0\).  
2. \(|xy|=|x|\cdot|y|\).  
3. \(|\dfrac{x}{y}|=\dfrac{|x|}{|y|}\), if \(y\ne0\).  
4. \(|x+y|\le |x|+|y|\) (**triangle inequality**).  
:::

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="ğŸ§¾ Proof of the Properties"}
- **(1)** By definition, \(|x|\) is the distance to the origin. Distance is never negative, and it is zero only when the point itself is the origin (\(x=0\)).  

- **(2)** Let \(x,y\in\mathbb{R}\). Since the sign of a product is the product of the signs,  
  \[
  |xy| = (\pm x)\cdot(\pm y) = |x|\cdot |y|.
  \]

- **(3)** For \(y\ne0\), simply divide the equality from the previous property:  
  \[
  |x/y| = \frac{|x|}{|y|}.
  \]

- **(4) Triangle Inequality:** from the geometric interpretation, \(|x+y|\) represents the distance between \(0\) and \(x+y\). This distance can never exceed the sum of the distances from \(x\) and \(y\) to \(0\). Formally:  
  \[
  |x+y|^2 = (x+y)^2 = x^2 + 2xy + y^2 \le (|x|+|y|)^2,
  \]
  which implies \(|x+y|\le |x|+|y|\).
:::

# Worked Examples

::: {.callout-note title="ğŸ§® Example 1"}
Solve:
\[
|x| = 3
\]

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Solution"}
By definition:  
- If \(x\ge0\), then \(|x|=x=3 \Rightarrow x=3\).  
- If \(x<0\), then \(|x|=-x=3 \Rightarrow x=-3\).  

âœ… **Solution:** \(\{-3,3\}\).
:::
:::

---

::: {.callout-note title="ğŸ§® Example 2"}
Solve:
\[
|x-2| < 5
\]

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Solution"}
\(|x-2|<5 \iff -5 < x-2 < 5 \iff -3 < x < 7\).  

âœ… **Solution:** \((-3,7)\).
:::
:::

# Absolute Value Inequalities

::: {.callout-note title="ğŸ“– Definition"}
An **absolute value inequality** is an inequality involving absolute value, such as:
\[
|f(x)| \{<, \le, >, \ge\} a
\]
with \(a\ge0\).  
The solution depends on the piecewise definition of the modulus.
:::

---

# Practice Exercises

::: {.callout-note title="ğŸ“ Exercises"}
1. Solve: \(|x+1|\le4\).  
2. Solve: \(|2x-3|>5\).  
3. Solve: \(|x^2-1|<3\).  
4. Verify whether \(|x+y|\le |x|+|y|\) for \(x=2, y=-5\).  
:::

::: {.callout-important collapse=true title="âœ… Answer Key"}
1. \(-5\le x+1\le4 \Rightarrow -6\le x\le3\).  
2. \(|2x-3|>5 \Rightarrow 2x-3>5\) or \(2x-3<-5\) â‡’ \(x>4\) or \(x<-1\).  
3. \(|x^2-1|<3 \Rightarrow -3<x^2-1<3 \Rightarrow -2<x^2<4\). Since \(x^2\ge0\), we get \(0\le x^2<4 \Rightarrow -2<x<2\).  
4. \(|2+(-5)|=|-3|=3\) and \(|2|+|{-5}|=2+5=7\). Indeed, \(3\le7\).  
:::
